jalds.alds.ds.heaps
Interface Heap

All Known Implementing Classes:
AbstractHeap, MaxHeapImpl, MinHeapImpl
public interface Heap

(From Mastering Algorithms with C) Heaps : Trees organized so that we can determine the node with the largest value quickly. The cost to preserve this property is less than that of keeping the data sorted. We can also organize a heap so that we can determine the smallest value just as easily. There are two kinds of heaps min and max heap, in a max heap for every node the parent is greater than equal to the child node. Heaps are stored in arrays, the left and right child of any node i is 2(i)+1 and 2i+2 and parent of any node at position i in an array is (i-1)/2

Author:
Devender Gollapally

Method Summary
 SortableObject extract()
          Extract the root node from the heap, this will either be the object with the max value or the min value depending on weather it is a max heap or a min heap.
 void insert(SortableObject sortableObject)
          Insert a new object into the heap, if this violates the heap property then another procedure is called to fix it.
 int size()
          Number of nodes in a heap
 

Method Detail

insert

void insert(SortableObject sortableObject)
Insert a new object into the heap, if this violates the heap property then another procedure is called to fix it.

Parameters:
sortableObject -

extract

SortableObject extract()
Extract the root node from the heap, this will either be the object with the max value or the min value depending on weather it is a max heap or a min heap. The root node is extracted from the heap and the root node is replaced with the very last node, then the heap property is checked by comparing the root node with both its child and replaced with the child that is the greatest difference.

Returns:

size

int size()
Number of nodes in a heap

Returns:
